analytic.title: International Journal of Refractory Metals & Hard Materials

biblStruct.note: Received 22 July 2019; Received in revised form 9 October 2019; Accepted 13 October 2019

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Refractory metal High entropy alloy Hot forging Precipitation Strengthening mechanism

div.p: A TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 refractory high entropy alloy was prepared by powder metallurgy and subsequently subjected to hot forging. The precipitation behavior and its effects on compression properties were studied. Results show that the as-sintered TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy has a single BCC phase. The primary BCC phase is thermodynamically instable, and decomposes into BCC (Ti, Nb, Ta)-rich matrix and HCP (Zr, Al)-rich precipitates after hot forging. The precipitates are much harder than the matrix, and have significant strengthening effect. The hot-worked TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy has a high compressive yield strength of 1740 MPa with a considerable compressive ductility of 12% at room temperature. The precipitation strengthening contributes about 51% while the grainboundary strengthening contributes 35% to the increment of the yield strength.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Refractory high entropy alloys (RHEAs) are a new class of multicomponent materials, which have recently received much attention because of their attractive elevated-temperature mechanical properties [1][2][3]. RHEAs are generally based on five or more refractory metals, but may also contain other low density elements, and typically have a BCC crystal structure [4][5][6]. For example, the first generation RHEAs, WMoTaNb and WMoTaNbV, show very slight decrease in yield strength with an increase in temperature, and have a yield strength above 400 MPa at 1600 °C [7]. However, the heavy metallic elements result in a high density (> 12 g/cm 3 ). Attempts to reduce the density led to the designing of the second generation RHEAs, in which W and/or Ta were replaced with low density elements, such as Ti, Zr, V, Nb, Cr and Al [8,9]. RHEAs belonging to this system usually have densities range from 5.5-10 g/cm 3 and good specific strength at high temperatures [10]. The well-known TaNbHfZrTi alloy, with a density of 9.94 g/cm 3 , exhibits high strength and good ductility at temperatures from 25 °C to 1000 °C [10]. On the other hand, some low-density RHEAs can be strengthened by second phase precipitates. For example, the precipitation of the C14 phase in Al 0.5 CrNbTi 2 V 0.5 alloy leads to an increase of about 200 MPa in yield strength [11], and the precipitation of the B2 phase in AlMo 0.5 NbTa 0.5 TiZr alloy resultes in an ultrahigh specific strength at room temperature [12].

However, the essential characteristic of sluggish diffusion makes precipitation process very slow in high entropy alloys. For example, the precipitation of a HCP phase in HfNbTaTiZr RHEA occurs after being annealed for about 100 h [13], and the precipitation of a Cr-rich σ phase in CrMnFeCoNi alloy needs an annealing time above 500 days [14]. Recently, it is reported that thermo-mechanical processing (TMP) can stimulate precipitation in high entropy alloys [15]. Zhang, et al. [16] observed the phase transformation or precipitation in CoCrFeMnNi alloy during compression based on in-situ high-pressure synchrotron radiation. It was claimed that, compared to temperature, pressure is a more powerful parameter in terms of promoting the phase transformation. During deformation, crystalline defects such as vacancies, dislocations and stacking faults formed, promoting diffusion and leading to an earlier nucleation of precipitates [17]. Besides, TMP methods such as hot forging and hot rolling can eliminate casting defects and refine microstructures, and thus, improve mechanical properties of RHEAs. But up to now, there is very few research focusing on hot-worked RHEAs. The precipitation behavior and its effects on mechanical properties of hot-worked RHEAs remain unclear.

In the present work, TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy were prepared by powder metallurgy (PM), and subsequently underwent hot forging. The microstructures and mechanical properties of the hot-worked TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy were studied. Precipitation behavior and strengthening mechanism were discussed, aiming to clarify the effects of precipitation on mechanical properties.

div.head: Experimental
div.p: Elemental powders were used to prepare TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy through PM method. The purities of Ti, Nb, Ta, Zr and Al powders were all above 99.5%. The average particle sizes of the above powders were 41.5 μm, 28.2 μm, 28.1 μm, 18.6 μm and 27.5 μm, respectively. The elemental powders were blended with a high efficiency blender (V-type VH-50, Yupan, Nanjing, China) for 10 h under argon atmosphere. The powder mixtures were compacted via cold isostatic pressing (CIP) at a pressure of 200 MPa. The compacts were sintered at 1300 °C for 16 h under vacuum of 1 × 10 -3 Pa followed by furnace cooling. Cylindrical samples with a diameter of 30 mm and a height of 45 mm were machined from the as-sintered compacts, and then encapsulated in stainless steel cans to avoid severe oxidation and potential fracture during hot forging. The samples were then hot forged at 1200 °C with a total height reduction of 50%, followed by furnace cooling. After hot forging, the stainless steel covering was removed by an electric spark cuttiang machine.

Compression tests at room temperature were conducted in air using hydraulic testing machine (Instron 8802) at a strain rate of 0.001 s -1 . Cylindrical specimens used for compression tests were cut from the asforged compacts with an axial direction parallel to the forging direction. The dimensions of testing specimens are 6 mm in diameter and 9 mm in height. The specimen surface was mechanically polished and kept parallel to the punches. The phase analysis was performed by using X-ray diffraction (XRD, Advance D8) with Cu Kα radiation. Microstructural examination was conducted using a scanning electron microscope (SEM, Helios Nanolab G3 UC) equipped with a backscattered electron (BSE) detector and an energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX). The elemental distribution was analyzed by using EDX and electron probe microanalysis (EPMA, JXA-8530F). Specimens for SEM and EPMA were prepared from longitudinal cross-sections of the as-forged samples. The details of microstructures were studied by using a transmission electron microscope (TEM, Titan G2 60-300) equipped with a high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) detector. Specimens for TEM were prepared by using focused ion beam (FIB) apparatus. The microhardness in local areas were measured by an IBIS Nano-indentation tester equipped with a Berkovich diamond indenter.

div.head: Results
div.p: The density of the as-sintered TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy was determined to be 6.7 g/cm 3 by Archimedes method. The relative density was then calculated to be about 92%. Microstructures of the as-sintered TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy are shown in Fig. 1. The secondary electron (SE) image taken at a low magnification presents some residual pores (Fig. 1(a)). The back-scattered electron (BSE) image taken around grain boundaries shows almost a single phase with very few nano-scaled precipitates (Fig. 1(b)). XRD results show a single phase of BCC crystal structure in the RHEA in the as-sintered state. The lattice parameter of the BCC phase was determined to be 3.355 Å. The nano-scaled precipitates could not be detected in the XRD patterns, may due to the low volume fraction. The similar diffraction angles of the precipitates and the matrix could also lead to such results [17]. Fig. 1(d)~(h) show the chemical composition profiles in the as-sintered TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy (obtained from EDX). It can be observed that the five constituent elements distribute homogeneously, indicating that the elemental powder had formed a uniform phase. Compared with similar compositional RHEAs prepared by casting [18,19], the present as-sintered alloy shows a much more uniform distribution of component elements.

Fig. 2 shows the microstructures of the as-forged TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy. After hot forging, the residual pores were totally eliminated, and a dense morphology was obtained. A high magnification image shows precipitation of (Zr, Al)-rich phase in the as-forged TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy. The (Zr, Al)-rich precipitates distribute homogeneously with an average size of about 1 μm, as shown in Fig. 2(a) and 2(b). The volume fraction of the precipitates was measured to be 30.5% by a Digimizer Image Analysis Software using SEM-BSE images. XRD results of the asforged TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy verified the existence of the BCC phase and the HCP (Zr, Al)-rich phase. Similar phase decomposition behavior had been reported in Hf 0.5 Nb 0.5 Ta 0.5 Ti 1.5 Zr and HfNbTaTiZr RHEAs subjected to long time of annealing [13,18]. Fig. 2(d)~(h) give the chemical composition profiles in the as-forged TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy by using EPMA. Obviously, Ti, Nb and Ta are rich in matrix while Zr and Al are rich in precipitates. Table 1 gives the compositions of the RHEA at different states. The composition of the RHEA in as-sintered state is very close to the nominal composition. In the as-forged state, the BCC phase has a higher content of Ti, Nb and Ta than the nominal composition, while the contents of Zr and Al are lower than the nominal composition. The HCP phase, conversely, has a high content of Zr and Al with a small amount of Ti, Nb and Ta.

TEM was used to further observe the microstructures of the asforged TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy, as shown in Fig. 3. Both STEM HADDF image and bright field image show a dual phase structure. The grain size of the matrix is about 1 μm. The SAED results clearly demonstrate that the crystal structures of the matrix and precipitates are BCC and HCP, respectively. The micro-hardness of the TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy investigated by using nano-indentation is shown in Fig. 4. The applied maximum load is 20mN. The micro-hardness and Young's modulus are 763 HV and 139GPa, respectively, for the as-sintered alloy. As for the hot-forged alloy, the indentation of the matrix and the precipitates show a substantial difference in the size. The micro-hardness and Young's modulus are 579 HV and 120GPa for the matrix, respectively, while those for the precipitates are 1216 HV and 172GPa, respectively. The HCP (Zr, Al)-rich phase is much harder than the BCC phase, which indicates that the (Zr, Al)-rich precipitates can act as a strengthening phase in the RHEA.

The compression behavior of the as-forged TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy is shown in Fig. 5. The stress-strain curve presents a good combination of strength and plasticity. The mechanical properties of the as-forged TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy are as follows: σ 0.2 = 1740 MPa, σ m = 2031 MPa, and δ = 12% at room temperature. In view of the low density (7.3 g/ cm 3 determined by Archimedes method), the hot-worked TiNb-Ta 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy has a high specific strength. A direct comparison of the mechanical properties of the TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy with other RHEAs is shown in Fig. 5(b) [4,20]. Most RHEAs show high strength but brittle, or high plasticity but soft. The RHEAs with high compressive yield strength (> 1800 MPa) were found, mostly, containing six components, such as Al 0.4 Hf 0.6 NbTaTiZr and Al 0.5 NbTa 0.8 Ti 1.5 V 0.2 Zr. The high strength of those RHEAs is mainly due to the strong solid-solution strengthening with limited plasticity. Compared to as-cast RHEAs, the hot-worked TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy possesses both high yield strength and considerable plasticity. The microstructures of the TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy after compression were studied, as shown in Fig. 6. The images were taken from the longitudinal section of the compressed specimens. The low magnification image presents uniform plastic deformation without any local shear band. The (Zr, Al)-rich precipitates keep a random distribution after RT compression. A higher magnification image shows that micro-cracks prefer to occur in the (Zr, Al)-rich precipitates rather than in the matrix, which is similar to the fracture characteristics in many metal matrix composites [21,22], and indicating that the (Zr, Al)-rich precipitates can deteriorate the plasticity of the RHEAs.

div.head: Precipitation behavior
div.p: So far, several physical parameters have been proposed to synergistically predict structural stability and phase formation in HEAs [5], such as the enthalpy of mixing (ΔH mix ) [23], the atomic-size difference (δ) [23], the entropy of mixing (ΔS mix ) [24,25], the parameter Ω [24, 25] . and the valence electron concentration (VEC) The calculation methods of the above parameters and the calculated values of the TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy are given in Table 2. The ΔH mix = -10.59 kJ/mol, δ = 4.18% and Ω = 2.71 simultaneously indicate a single solid-solution phase in the TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy. The VEC is about 4.25, which suggests a BCC structure. The phase prediction agrees with the experimental observations of the as-sintered TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy.

The above prediction is essentially for the phase equilibrium at high temperatures close to the melting point, where the mixing-entropy effect could be fully utilized to enhance the formation of solid-solutions [13]. According to Ostwald's Rule [26], high-temperature phases often form first during cooling/crystallization. It means that, with conventional preparation methods such as casting, the HEAs always form a single solid-solution phase first, and when being cooled down to room temperature, possible phase transformation or precipitation could be kinetically hindered due to the insufficient time for diffusion [16,27].

Even if being prepared by PM with furnace cooling, the cooling rate is still too fast for HEAs to accomplish possible phase transformation. Senkov, al. [28] demonstrated that the decomposition of BCC phase in HfNbTaTiZr alloy requires a very slow cooling rate (< 15 °C/min), due to the sluggish diffusion effect of HEAs. Therefore, the BCC phase in the as-sintered TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy may be thermodynamically instable. Precipitation or phase transformation has been reported in some HEAs annealed at intermediate temperature or subjected to pressure [13,14,16,17]. As for the present TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy, an obvious precipitation behavior of BCC → BCC (Ti, Nb, Ta)-rich matrix + HCP (Zr, Al)-rich precipitates was detected after hot forging. To explain the phase decomposition in the TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy, the crystal structure of the constituent metal and the binary phase diagrams formed by the RHEA's constituents should be considered. The Ta and Nb can form a solidsolution phase for all concentrations and maintains a BCC structure at both low and high temperatures. According to the TieNb and TieTa binary phase diagrams, the BCC solid-solution phase also forms for all compositions at a temperature above 900 °C. But, Zr and Al have a strong trend to form intermetallic phases at temperatures range from 25 °C to 1275 °C. Table 3 gives the enthalpy of mixing, ΔH mix , between each two elements in Ti-Nb-Ta-Zr-Al system [19]. Apparently, Al has large negative enthalpy of mixing with other refractory elements especially with Zr, indicating that Al plays an important role in the formation of intermetallic phases. As mentioned above, annealing at intermediate temperatures or TMP can stimulate precipitation in high entropy alloys. Therefore, the (Zr, Al)-rich precipitates could form during hot forging.

div.head: Strengthening mechanisms
div.p: The hot-worked TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy presents compressive yield strength (Fig. 5). The enhanced strength mainly comes from two parts: strength of the matrix (σ m ) and strengthening from the precipitates (Δσ p ). In the RHEA matrix, solid-solution strengthening (Δσ s ) and grain-boundary strengthening (Δσ g ) play important roles, and the σ m could be roughly estimated as:
div.formula: = + ∆ + ∆ σ σ σ σ m a s g(1)
div.p: where Δσ a = 209 MPa is the intrinsic strength the alloy calculated using the rule of mixing (ROM). The solid-solution strengthening can be estimated from [29]:
div.formula: ∆ = σ AGf c i i i 4/3 2/3(3)
div.p: where A is a material-dependent dimensionless constant of the order of 0.04 [29]. G is the shear modulus of the alloy, which is estimated to be 41.6GPa using the Rule of Mixture (ROM), f i is the mismatch parameter, and c i is the atomic percentage of the i th element. Using values of f i in BCC HEAs from literatures [29,30], Δσ s is calculated to be 804 MPa in the TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy. The value of the intrinsic strength plus the solid-solution strengthening is 1013 MPa, which is close to the yield strength of RHEAs with a similar composition prepared by casting method (~1100 MPa) [31]. After hot forging, the grain size is significantly refined, and the grain-boundary strengthening can be estimated by the Hall-Petch Eq. [32], expressed as follow:
where k is the Hall-Petch coefficient, d is the grain size of the present RHEA, and d 0 represents the grain size of corresponding alloy prepared

div.p: A comparative analysis between the threshold values and the calculated values of the TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy.

div.p: Calculated values

div.p: -15 kJ/mol ≤ ΔH mix ≤ 5 kJ/mol -10.59
div.formula: ∆ =-∑ = S c c R l n mix i n i i 1
div.p: A high value of ΔS mix is important in stabilizing the solid-solution phases 12.96
div.formula: Ω = T m ΔS mix /|ΔH mix | Ω ≥ 1.1 2.71 = ∑ = VEC c VEC ( ) i n i i 1
div.p: VEC < 6.87 for BCC structure 4.25 by casting. In this work, k is 240Mpa•μm 1/2 adopted from RHEAs with a similar composition [33], d is about 1 μm measured from the STEM HAADF image (Fig. 3a), and d 0 is about 180 μm in the literature [34]. Thus, the Δσ g is calculated to be 223 MPa in the hot-worked TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy. the σ m is estimated to be 1236 MPa. After annealing, the fine precipitates distribute homogenously in the matrix. The effect of the rigid precipitates on the strength at ambient temperature can be expressed as follow [35]:
p m L D (5) where f L and f D are parameters associated with the load bearing effect and the dislocation strengthening effect. The parameter f L is given by:
div.formula: = + f V l d d ( ) / 4 L p p p p (6)
div.p: where V p is the volume fraction of the precipitates, l p and d p are the length and diameter of the precipitates, respectively. As for the present RHEA, the V p is about 0.3. The precipitates are treated as spherical to simplify the calculation, and thus, d p is about 1 μm, and f L is calculated to be 0.15. The parameter f D is given by:
div.formula: = ∆ + ∆ f σ σ σ [( ) ( ) ] / D Orowan Thermal m 2 2 1 / 2
div.p: where Δσ Orowan is the stress increment caused by the impeding of dislocation motion, and Δσ Thermal is the stress increment due to thermal expansion mismatch between the matrix alloy and the reinforcements.
The stress increments are expressed as:
div.formula: Orowan p p p p 1/3 1 (7) ∆ = ∆ - σ k G b Va Tb d V [12 /(1 )
div.p: where b is the Burger vector (0.29 nm), k and a are material constants (k = 1.25 and a = 3.9 × 10 -6 K -1 ), ΔT is the value change from the processing temperature to the testing temperature. Thus, f D is calculated to be 0.10 at RT, and further, the Δσ p is estimated to be 328 MPa. Based on the above analyses, the yield strength of the TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy is calculated to be 1564 MPa, which is roughly close to the experimental result (1740 MPa). The yield strength of the hot-worked TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy is about 640 MPa higher than the RHEAs with a similar composition prepared by casting method [35]. It can be summarized that the precipitation strengthening contributes most to the strength increment (about 51%), and the grain-boundary strengthening acts as the second strengthening mechanism (contributes about 35%).

Moreover, the microstructures of the TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy after compression presented in Fig. 6 reveal that cracks prefer to originate at the precipitates rather than at the matrix or the interface, indicating that the interfacial bonding strength is strong enough to transfer load from matrix to precipitates. Since the precipitates are much harder than the matrix, the existence of the precipitates can bear high stress before fracture, and therefore, strengthening the alloy. However, coarse precipitates can result in strong stress concentration and lead to an early crack initiation [21,22]. It means that the precipitates can reduce the compression plasticity of the TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy. Therefore, the size and the volume fraction of the precipitates should be strictly controlled to balance the strength and the plasticity.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: The precipitation behavior and strengthening mechanism of the hotworked TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 RHEA were investigated, and the following conclusions can be drawn:

(1) The TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 RHEA prepared by powder metallurgy has a single BCC phase, but the BCC phase is thermodynamically instable. (2) The TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 RHEA decomposes into two phases, the BCC matrix and the HCP (Zr, Al)-rich precipitates after hot forging. The precipitates have an average size of about 1 μm and distribute homogeneously in the matrix. (3) The hot-worked TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 RHEA has a high compressive yield strength of 1740 MPa with a considerable compressive plasticity of 12% at room temperature. The precipitation strengthening and the grain-boundary strengthening contribute about 51% and 35% to the strength increment, respectively.

figure.head: Fig. 1 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 1. Microstructures of the as-sintered TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy: (a) SE image shows the residual pores; (b) BSE image around grain boundary; (c) XRD patterns; (d)( h) elemental distribution of Fig. 1(b).

figure.head: Fig. 2 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 2. Microstructures of the as-forged TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy: (a) BSE image gives an overview (b) morphology of the precipitates; (c) XRD patterns; (d)~(h) elemental distribution of Fig. 2(b).

figure.head: Fig. 3 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 3. Detailed characteristics of the as-forged TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy: (a) STEM HAADF image of the RHEA; (b) SAED patterns of the matrix; (c) bright field image of the precipitates; (d) SAED patterns of the precipitate.

figure.head: Fig. 4 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 4. Nano-indentation hardness of the TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy: (a) and (b) as-sintered alloy; (c) and (d) as-forged alloy.

figure.head: Fig. 5 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 5. Compression behavior of the as-forged TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy: (a) Engineering stress-strain curve during compression; (b) comparison of compressive yield strength vs. compressive plasticity in various HEAs [4,20].

figure.head: Fig. 6 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 6. Microstructures of the TiNbTa 0.5 ZrAl 0.5 alloy after compression: (a) low magnification shows uniform deformation (b) high magnification image shows microcracks at the precipitates.
